Glenn Youngkin, the new governor of Virginia, began his role on January 15, 2022, joined by the first woman of color to be elected to statewide office in Virginia, Lieutenant Governor Winsome Sears, who is also African American, and the first Latino to hold statewide office in Virginia, Attorney General Jason Miyares.

After Glenn Youngkin, a Republican, became Virginia's governor on January 15, 2022, he formed an administration with a diverse team, including Winsome Sears as the first woman of color and African American lieutenant governor, and Jason Miyares as the first Latino attorney general. This development led Douglas Wilder, the former Democratic Governor of Virginia, to acknowledge that Republicans had made a significant advancement in attracting diverse communities, particularly African Americans and Latinos, by "one-upping" Democrats. Wilder also warned that Democrats should not take the Black community's support for granted. The inauguration took place during the second year of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

Upon assuming office as Virginia's governor, Glenn Youngkin, a Republican, established a diverse administration, with Winsome Sears as the first woman of color and African American lieutenant governor, and Jason Miyares as the first Latino attorney general. The inauguration occurred in the midst of the second year of the COVID-19 pandemic, and Youngkin's first week in office coincided with the North American winter storm of January 14-17, 2022.

Before his inauguration as Virginia's governor, Glenn Youngkin, a Republican, took part in a community service project at the Reconciliation Statue in Shockoe Bottom, an area that once housed the second largest domestic slave market in the US prior to the Civil War.
